titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Michael Lally Papers MSS.361
titlestmt.author: Collection processed by Stacey Flatt

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2023-06-13T13:54:35

physdesc.extent: in 88 manuscript boxes, 1 half manuscript box, 3 flat boxes, 2 custom flat boxes, 4 oversize flat boxes, 2 record cartons, and 3 flat-file folders

did.abstract: The Michael Lally Papers represent and document the life and work of New Jersey-born poet, screenwriter, small press publisher, and actor Michael Lally. The collection includes correspondence, screenplays, manuscripts, poems, drafts of articles, publicity, analog and digital audiovisual recordings of poetry readings and acting work samples, digital photographs, acting scripts, journals, calendars, scrapbooks, clippings, books, small press publications, address books, and posters, all dating from the 1950s to 2012, with the bulk of the material from the 1970s to the 2000s. An archived version of Lally's blog, http://lallysalley.blogspot.com/ which contains Lally's reviews and comments on movies, television shows, literature can also be found in this collection.
did.physloc: Some materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials are open without restrictions with the exception of Acting Contracts files located in Series II.B., Box 100.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Granary Books, Inc., 2012. The accession number associate with this purchase is 2012.361.

In 2019, http://lallysalley.blogspot.com/ was added to the web archive through the use of Archive-it. Archive-It uses web crawling technology to capture websites at a scheduled time and displays only an archived copy, from the resulting WARC file, of the website. The accession number associated with this website is 2019.071.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p:
Eight computer discs were deaccessioned after forensic imaging and analysis determined items contained no usable data or were duplicate material.
Movie titles existing in NYU's holdings were removed from the collection including Drugstore Cowboy, Ramona, Pump Up the Volume, White Fang, Basic Instinct, The Rapture, and Cool World.
A duplicate audiocassette for the JazzSpeak album was deaccessioned, while the CD copy was retained.
Publications and books that existed already in NYU's holdings. Duplicates of publications, books, and other print material were removed from the collection.

appraisal.head: Take Down Policy
appraisal.p: Archived websites are made accessible for purposes of education and research. NYU Libraries have given attribution to rights holders when possible; however, due to the nature of archival collections, we are not always able to identify this information.
If you hold the rights to materials in our archived websites that are unattributed, please let us know so that we may maintain accurate information about these materials.

If you are a rights holder and are concerned that you have found material on this website for which you have not granted permission (or is not covered by a copyright exception under US copyright laws), you may request the removal of the material from our site by submitting a notice, with the elements described below, to fales.library@nyu.edu

Please include the following in your notice: Identification of the material that you believe to be infringing and information sufficient to permit us to locate the material; your contact information, such as an address, telephone number, and email address; a statement that you are the owner, or authorized to act on behalf of the owner, of an exclusive right that is allegedly infringed and that you have a good-faith belief that use of the material in the manner complained of is not authorized by the copyright owner, its agent, or the law; a statement that the information in the notification is accurate and made under penalty of perjury; and your physical or electronic signature. Upon receiving a notice that includes the details listed above, we will remove the allegedly infringing material from public view while we assess the issues identified in your notice.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
The papers are arranged in three series, all of which have been further separated into subseries. The series and subseries arrangement of the papers is as follows:
Series I. Writings, Publishing, and Related Projects
Subseries I.A. Work Files
Subseries I.B. Publications
Subseries I.C. Readings and Events
Subseries I.D. Literary Correspondence
Subseries I.E. Publishing Correspondence
Series II. Screenwriting, Plays, and Acting
Subseries II.A. Screenplays, Plays, and Related
Subseries II.B. Acting and Voice Over Work
Subseries II.C. Correspondence
Series III. Personal
Subseries III.A. General
Subseries III.B. Correspondence

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p:
Michael Lally (1942- ) was born and raised in New Jersey. He joined the Air Force in 1962 and after four years left the service. Through the G.I. Bill he received his undergraduate and graduate degrees from the University of Iowa. In 1969, he moved to Washington, D.C. to teach at Trinity College. While in D.C. he became involved in the local poetry scene, where he established the Mass Transit poetry reading series which was considered an important incubator for Language Poetry, and launched a poetry publishing collective, Some of Us Press (SOUP) with wife Lee Lally, Ed Cox, and Tina Darragh. SOUP published Lally's book, The South Orange Sonnets, in 1972. In 1975 Lally separated from his first wife, the poet Lee Lally, and moved to New York, where he wrote poetry; founded a small publishing company, O Press; and also edited the anthology None of the Above: New Poets of the USA.
In 1982 Lally moved to Los Angeles to pursue opportunities in film and television as a writer and actor. He appeared in numerous movies, television episodes, and plays including Basic Instinct, White Fang, Father Dowling Mysteries, and Deadwood. In addition to writing his own original screenplays and plays, Lally was a script doctor in which he contributed to existing screenplays. During his time in Los Angeles, Lally co-founded the Poetry in Motion series (1988â€“1996), which received media attention for its mix of Hollywood celebrities and poets. While living in California Lally also helped found and edit the original Venice magazine.
Lally has published over 27 books of poetry and memoirs. His awards include the 92nd St. Y Poetry Center's Discovery Award for The South Orange Sonnets; numerous National Endowment for the Arts grants; and the 2000 American Book Award for It's Not Nostalgia. In 2006, Lally started the blog "Lally's Alley" (http://lallysalley.blogspot.com/) in which, as of 2019, he continues to write daily reflections on his personal life, movies, politics, and poetry. As of 2019, he is living and working in New Jersey.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p:
In 2012, the material was collected by Granary Books during two visits to Michael Lally's home in Maplewood, New Jersey. Much of the material had been preliminarily sorted and organized by Michael Lally. The collection was transported to Granary Books in New York City where portions were refoldered and rearranged.
In circa 2012-2013, the material was purchased by the Fales Library & Special Collections and transferred to NYU.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact fales.library@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

phystech.head: Electronic Records Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Advance notice is required for the use of computer records. Original physical digital media is restricted.

An access terminal for born-digital materials in the collection is available by appointment for reading room viewing and listening only. Researchers may view an item's original container and/or carrier, but the physical carriers themselves are not available for use because of preservation concerns.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Michael Lally Papers; MSS 361; box number; folder number, or electronic record identifier; The Fales Library & Special Collections, New York University.
To cite the archived website in this collection: Identification of item, date; Michael Lally Papers; MSS 361; Wayback URL; The Fales Library & Special Collections, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: In 2012, the material was collected during two visits from Michael Lally's home in Maplewood, New Jersey. Much of the material had been preliminarily sorted and organized by Michael Lally. The collection was transported to Granary Books in New York City where it was processed and a detailed inventory was created. Appoximately 80% of the physical material was re-foldered at that time, while maintaining most of Lally's original arrangement. The exception was the correspondence, which was interfiled, notating a code letter on each folder to identify Lally's original categories. These code letters identify correspondence received while he was at a particular location or friends he first met there. The following are the codes assigned to Lally's designations and notated on each folder: (D) Washington, D.C. letters and people; (I) Iowa letters and people; (L) L=A=N=G=U=A=G=E poets; (LA) Los Angeles, Hollywood, and California; and (N) New York City.

In circa 2012-2013, the material was purchased by the Fales Library & Special Collections and transferred to NYU. In 2019 a processing archivist performed a survey, using the seller inventory and determined the physical arrangement of the collect would largely remain as it was received from the seller, but arranged into three series, rather than the Granary Books' original six.

Material was kept in their existing folders when possible, maintaining their original titles, while any loose material, specifically the publications, were foldered and assigned labels created by the processing archivist. Some overstuffed folders were separated out into multiple folders. Any oversize material was unrolled and placed in appropriately-sized folders in boxes or flat-file drawers.

Born-digital material was inventoried, labeled, and imaged. Discs were processed using Forensic Toolkit, and video and audio were imaged and uploaded to permanent storage. A quarter of the discs were deaccessioned due to duplication, or simply too corrupted to open. New York University Libraries follow professional standards and best practices when imaging, ingesting, and processing born-digital material in order to maintain the integrity and authenticity of the content.

Sound and video recordings were grouped and stored by format and described to the box level. Commercially produced audiovisual material was removed from the collection and if it was found to exist in the NYU holdings, it was deaccessioned. Those items not in NYU's holdings were transferred to the Avery Fisher Center for Music and Media.

In 2019, an entry for the archived website was added to the finding aid in Series III.A. In 2022 a flat-file folder containing two poems dedicated to Lally was returned from the Preservation Lab after treatment and added as an instance to an existing title in Subseries III.B.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
The Michael Lally Papers contains material on both Lally's professional and personal life. This material includes a significant collection of correspondence specifically related to Lally's involvement with the L=A=N=G=U=A=G=E poets during their formative years, with small publishers, and with people in the poetry communities in Iowa City, Washington, D.C., and New York City during the 1970s through the 2000s. Lally's writing files include his manuscripts and drafts for poetry books and articles, as well as working files on his publishing companies, O Press and Some of Us Press (SOUP). A mix of paper and electronic files relate to his poetry readings through posters, publicity, and images from events. Small press publications and alternative journals in this collection contain many of Lally's writings, dating from the late 1960s through the 1990s, reflecting the output of poetry and literary communities during this time. Acting scripts, movie and play posters, publicity, and analog and digital audiovisual material represent Lally's work as an actor and screenwriter in Los Angeles during the 1980s through the 2000s. Personal journals, scrapbooks, calendars, address books, school yearbooks and papers, digital photographs, and correspondence with family and friends date from the 1950s to the 2000s.
An archived version of Lally's blog, http://lallysalley.blogspot.com/ where, as of 2019, he writes daily reflections on matters ranging from his personal life, movies, and politics to poetry. The blog was first captured in June 2019.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Two DVDs were transferred to Avery Fisher in July 2019: TV Show: Big Apple (Lally acted in) and Short Film: Being Born

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).

did.unittitle: Series I. Writings, Publishing, and Related Projects

physdesc.extent: in 53 manuscript boxes, 3 flat boxes, 3 oversize flat boxes, 1 record carton, and 2 flat-file folders

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
This series is divided into five subseries:
Subseries I.A. Work Files
Subseries I.B. Publications
Subseries I.C. Readings and Events
Subseries I.D. Literary Correspondence
Subseries I.E. Publishing Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains electronic and paper material related to Lally's work as an editor, poet, and freelance writer during the 1960s to 2000s, including writing and editing work files; publications containing Lally's work; video and audio recordings of readings and spoken albums; event publicity; correspondence with his literary colleagues; and correspondence with small publishers regarding his projects.

physdesc.extent: in 19 manuscript boxes, 1 flat box, and 1 oversize flat box

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material is arranged beginning with published work titles in alphabetical order, followed by the remaining files on his work kept in their original order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains Lally's writing files for published and unpublished works, notecards tracking his published works (1960s to 2009), and files related to his publishing ventures, O Press and Some of Us Press (SOUP). His work files on individual pieces and books typically contain notes, manuscripts, contracts, proofs, publicity, and correspondence, including files for The South Orange Sonnets, Catch My Breath, It Takes One to Know One, and It's Not Nostalgia. These work files also contain larger editing projects, including his work on the anthology None of the Above: New Poets of the USA which included works by L=A=N=G=U=A=G=E poets Ron Silliman, Bruce Andrews, and Ray DiPalma; New York School poets Alice Notley and Joe Brainard; and poets working outside any community association such as Patti Smith. Files containing unpublished loose poems are in this subseries, as well as chronological poetry manuscript books dating from the 1950s through the 1980s, his journals with writing ideas, and Lally's reviews of others' work. This subseries contains files on his first published piece Markings on the Wall including rejection slips, manuscript, and correspondence from the 1960s. Files with his unpublished biographies Loose Canon and Poor Moth Boy in the Moon are in this subseries. Lally's editorial work is also represented through his Franklin Library files and Venice Magazine files, which include photographs by musician Andy Summers.

unittitle.emph: It Takes One to Know One
On the Back of His Head

physdesc.extent: 14 manuscript boxes, 2 flat boxes, and 1 oversize flat box

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in alphabetical order by title. The inventory lists an alphabetical range by title, grouped by publication size.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These approximately 300 small and large circulation newspapers and magazines contain works by Lally which date primarily from the 1960s through the 1980s. Alternative press titles include All You Can Eat (1972), FagRag (1973), The Great Speckled Bird (1970-1971), and literary magazines Blue Suede Shoes (1971), L=A=N=G=U=A=G=E (1978-1980), and Buffalo Stamps (1972). Lally also contributed articles, editorials, reviews, letters, and poems to publications of a radical, political, counter-cultural and/or gay orientation including Campus Underground (1968â€“1969), Daily Rag (1973), Unicorn Times (circa 1974), Washington Review, (1979-1993, 2001), Washington Review of the Arts (1975-1977), and Woodwind(1972). Issues of Venice Magazine (1988, 1990, 1995) which Lally founded and edited are in this subseries. Black Box, a publication in audiocassette form and which Lally was editor for a time, can also be found in this subseries. The publication, Matchbook, which is 1-word poems contained within real matchbooks is in this subseries.

did.unittitle: New Letters -- The Poetry Project Newsletter
All You Can Eat -- Middle Earth
The New Patriot -- U.S. Farm News

physdesc.extent: in 2 manuscript boxes, 2 flat boxes, 1 record carton, 1 oversize flat box, and 2 flat-file folders
in 27 computer, audio, and video files

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in alphabetical order by title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains material related to Michael Lally's performances as a poet, including poetry readings and recorded spoken albums. Contracts, publicity, posters, ephemera, reviews, and audiovisual and digital recordings of Lally's poetry readings and events date from the 1970s to the 2000s. Lally's Poetry in Motion series files contain publicity and planning material related to readings performed by a mix of Hollywood celebrities (Alec Baldwin, Robert Downey, Jr., and Ally Sheedy) and poets (Jack Grapes, Hubert Selby, Jr., and Wanda Coleman) in the 1980s and 1990s in while he was living in Los Angeles. See Series II.C. for correspondence files on this project. Electronic records in this subseries contain poetry reading albums and other event recordings, including Jazzspeak: A Word Collection , Michael Lally: Lost Angels, and Poets Against War. Digital images of a 2004 poetry reading and a digital video recording of a documentary on Hubert Selby, Jr. with a Lally interview are also in this subseries.

physdesc.extent: in 18 manuscript boxes, 1 oversize flat box, and 2 flat-file folders

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in alphabetical order by file title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains correspondence with poets, writers, and colleagues, which often include manuscripts and ephemera. Lally's correspondence documents his involvement with the avante garde L=A=N=G=U=A=G=E poet group during their formative years in the 1960s and 1970s, as well as the poetry communities in Iowa City, Washington, D.C., and New York City. Correspondence is especially extensive with those he collaborated with and published through O Press and Some of Us Press (SOUP) in the 1970s, including Bruce Andrews, Max Blagg, Joe Brainard, Gerald Burns, Tina Darragh, Ray DiPalma, Tim Dlugos, Etheridge Knight, Jerome Sala, and Terence Winch. This series also contains four poster-sized message paintings by Sylvia Schuster.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in alphabetical order by file title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains correspondence dating from the 1970s through the 2000s which had been separated from Lally's manuscript files, specifically relating to the publication of his works through smaller presses. Those correspondents with extensive files include Dennis Cooper with Little Ceasar Press, John and Elaine Gill from The Crossing Press, and George Mattingly from Blue Wind Press and Something Else Press. This subseries also contains a large collection of correspondence, mail art, and manuscripts from Jim Haining of Salt Lick Press, of which Lally's book Catch My Breath was one of the company's best selling works.

Series II. Screenwriting, Plays, and Acting

physdesc.extent: in 20 manuscript boxes, 1 half manuscript box, 2 cartons, 1 flat box, 1 oversize flat box, and 2 flat-file folders

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
This series is divided into three subseries:
Subseries II.A. Screenplays, Plays, and Related
Subseries II.B. Actings and Voice Over Work
Subseries II.C. Correspondence
Material within each subseries are arranged in alphabetical order by file title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains material accumulated primarily while Lally worked as an actor, screenwriter, and playwright in Los Angeles during the 1980s through the 2000s. Files include screenplays, notated actor scripts, writing and acting contracts, publicity, playbills, posters, audiovisual recordings, and correspondence with friends and colleagues in Los Angeles. Electronic records contain voiceover and acting demo samples, and digital images of Lally and castmates in costume on the set of the television show Deadwood.

did.unittitle: Subseries II.A. Screenplays, Plays, and Related

physdesc.extent: in 14 manuscript boxes, 1 flat box, and 1 flat-file folder

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A significant portion of this subseries contains edited television show episodes, movie screenplays, and stage plays written, co-written, or script-doctored by Lally, illustrating the many facets of working as a screenwriter in Los Angeles during the 1980s through the 2000s. Notable scripts in which he contributed include the movies Drugstore Cowboy, Fogbound, and Pump Up the Volume. Original works include his autobiographical piece, Fly Boy, a play adapted from his book Hollywood Magic, Chicks With Dicks, and Rhythm of Torn Stars. This subseries also includes posters for Lally's plays Rhythm of Torn Stars and Hollywood Magic; assorted movie and television ideas; and screenplay contracts.

did.unittitle: Subseries II.B. Acting and Voice Over Work

physdesc.extent: in 4 manuscript boxes, one half manuscript box, 1 flat box, 1 oversize flat box, 1 record carton, and 1 flat-file folder

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes material related to Lally's work as a film, stage, and voice over actor in Los Angeles during the 1980s through the 2000s. Notated movie and television episode actor scripts include Basic Instinct, Cool World, Deadwood, Ed, JAG, Father Dowling Mysteries, Ramona Has Two Lovers, and White Fang. Sound and video recordings in both digital and analog form contain demo reels used for auditions with samples of Lally's appearances in television show episodes and movies, as well as his voice work in advertising commercials. This subseries also contains publicity for movies and television shows, including posters and advertising booklets for Phobia, The Nesting, and Last Rites. This subseries also contains Lally's play programs, call sheets, and acting contracts.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: These files are restricted until Michael Lally's death. Personal information must be redacted before they are available for use by researchers.

Video Recordings -- Movies, Plays, TV Show Episodes, and Demos used for Auditions

physdesc.extent: in 3 manuscript boxes and 1 flat-file folder

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains correspondence from friends and colleagues Lally accumulated while living in Los Angeles as an actor, playwright, and screenwriter in the 1980s through the 2000s. Of note are letters from actors Sharon Stone, Carrie Fisher, and Michael O'Keefe. Letters and a 1987 collage Lally by artist Paul Harryn can also be found in this subseries. Poetry written by friends for Lally's 50th birthday is in this subseries. This subseries also contains correspondence for Lally's Poetry in Motion project, which was a spoken word series co-created with Eve Brandstein in 1988. Lally's series brought together poets and Hollywood celebrities including Alec Baldwin, Robert Downey, Jr., Ally Sheedy, and Michael O'Keefe for readings. See Series I.C. for publicity files on this project.

did.unittitle: Poetry in Motion and Hollywood Review

physdesc.extent: in 20 manuscript boxes, 2 flat boxes, 2 custom flat boxes, and 2 flat-file folders

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
This series is divided into two subseries:
Subseries III.A. General
Subseries III.B. Correspondence
Material is arranged within each subseries in alphabetical order by file title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains material related to Lally's personal life including school papers and ephemera; scrapbooks; journals and notebooks; press interviews and clippings; address books; calendars and date books; and correspondence with family and friends. This series also includes electronic files containing casual and professional images of Lally. An archived version of his blog, http://lallysalley.blogspot.com/ can also be found in this series. The blog was first captured in June 2019.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: New site crawls are accrued annually.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Due to technical or privacy issues, archived websites may not be exact copies of the original website at the time of the web crawl. Certain file types will not be captured dependent on how they are embedded in the site. Other parts of websites that the crawler has difficulty capturing includes Javascript, streaming content, database-driven content, and highly interactive content. Full-Text searches of archived websites are available at https://archive-it.org/organizations/567.

physdesc.extent: in 16 manuscript boxes, 2 flat boxes, 3 oversize flat boxes, 2 flat-file folders

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains Lally's address books, calendars, and daybooks from 1982 to 2011 which track his daily routine and appointments. Wall calendar pages with illustrations by George Schneeman, and a 1979 Koff calendar with nude photographs of male poets Lally, Charles Bukowski, Bill Berkson, Tom Carey, John Godfrey, and Bill Kushner can also be found in this subseries. Material from Lally's time attending St. Benedict's Preparatory School, Trinity College, and the University of Iowa includes class papers, publications, MFA thesis notes, workshop files, and yearbooks. This subseries also contains documentation of Lally's service in the Air Force in the 1960s, as well as files related to Lally and his first wife Lee's marriage and divorce, dating from the 1960s to the 1990s. Journals and notebooks from 1962 to the 1990s contain vacation diaries, an acting journal, and financial records kept by Lally. Scrapbooks contain juvenilia from Lally's birth and early childhood, clippings, play programs, publicity, and documentation of his political activism in the 1960s. This subseries also includes political posters by Sharon Gregory and political buttons collected by Lally. Clippings and transcripts of interviews profiling Lally date from 1979 to 2011. This subseries also contains files on his grants and awards, resumes, and an original piece of artwork by Lally of friends Ray and Betsi DiPalma from the 1970s.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: New site crawls are accrued annually.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Due to technical or privacy issues, archived websites may not be exact copies of the original website at the time of the web crawl. Certain file types will not be captured dependent on how they are embedded in the site. Other parts of websites that the crawler has difficulty capturing includes Javascript, streaming content, database-driven content, and highly interactive content. Full-Text searches of archived websites are available at https://archive-it.org/organizations/567.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: Robots.txt (a piece of code designed to limit crawler activity within a website) was ignored.
Crawl was limited to domains and subdomains of lallysalley.blogspot.com in order to remain within the collection scope and data constraints.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Personal culture blog of Michael Lally.

did.unittitle: Lee and Michael Wedding and Divorce

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains correspondence from 1966 to 1997 with Lally's friends and family. Correspondence from Lally's first wife Lee while he served in the Air Force describe their courtship and wedding plans, as well as cards and notes after their marriage. Letters from friends to Lee Lally from the 1960s and 1970s kept by Michael Lally are in this series. This subseries also contains letters from Lally's other two wives and his three children. Letters from Lally's parents James and Irene date from 1949 to 1973, sharing news of the family and events in their lives. Correspondence from Lally's siblings are also in this subseries, including letters from 1953-2010 from brother Campion Lally who served as a priest at Franciscan Chapel Center in Japan. A significant portion of the letters from friends in this subseries were sent while Lally was serving in the Air Force in the 1960s.
